awd_abstract_narration:
This project will explore the efficacy of using a competency framework as an organizing system for research security training for U.S. researchers.  It will create an online module for research security training.  This activity will focus on the importance of principled international collaboration to the U.S. research enterprise and the ongoing threats posed to this enterprise by improper foreign government influence. This project directly addresses the need to strengthen the security of U.S. government-supported research and development, per the National Security Presidential Memorandum – 33 (NSPM-33) and the CHIPS plus Science Act of 2022 (P.L. 117-167).  Dissemination and use of this training will better protect U.S. research interests from both foreign and domestic risks and threats. The training module will be Internet-based, scalable, flexible, and widely accessible to researchers and stakeholders in a variety of settings, including researchers with disabilities. The project will develop a research security competency framework as the design basis for the training module. Training will be customized for distinct stakeholder groups within the U.S. research ecosystem and use real-world case studies and hypothetical scenarios to progress learners through increasingly advanced levels of knowledge and skills. The development of the research security training module series is collaboratively funded by the National Science Foundation (NSF), the National Institutes of Health (NIH), the Department of Energy (DOE), and the Department of Defense (DOD).

This research security training module focused on the importance of principled international collaboration will be designed and developed in consultation with a Content Expert Group, which includes of experts in research security across government. The project will use the ADDIE Model to sequence design and development activities. Methods drawn from the Universal Design for Learning Guidelines, Mayer’s 12 Principles of Multimedia Instruction, and the revised Bloom’s Taxonomy will guide instructional and curriculum design activities. Following the initial design work and consultation, focus groups will be convened to acquire rapid and ongoing design and development input from research stakeholder groups. Focus groups will represent key stakeholder groups within the U.S. research ecosystem, such as principal investigators, visiting international faculty, and post-doctoral fellows. The project team will assess the effectiveness of the module by using the Kirkpatrick Model for course evaluation to test module iterations. Kirkpatrick Level 1 assessments will evaluate the reaction of learners to the module; Level 2 assessments will evaluate the extent to which learners acquired the intended research security knowledge and skills. Following end user testing, evaluation, and revisions to the design, the module will be made available for dissemination to research security stakeholders, including university-based researchers, undergraduate and graduate students, academic administrators, research security administrators, and researchers and staff in government agencies and national laboratories.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Project Title: Research Security Training: The Importance of International Collaboration

PI: Kevin L. Doran, AUI

Co-PIs: Adam Reed, AUI; James Howard, AUI

Awardee: Associated Universities, Inc.

Award Number: NSF 2230538

PoP: November 1, 2022, to October 31, 2024

Award amount: $499338.00

Executive Summary

This project developed an interactive training module on The Importance of International Collaboration as part of a larger initiative to educate researchers, students, and administrators on research security. The module underscores the vital role of international partnerships in scientific progress while addressing concerns about research integrity, undue foreign influence, and best practices for maintaining secure and transparent collaborations.

Designed for federally funded researchers and institutions, this module offers real-world scenarios and decision-making exercises that help participants navigate the complexities of global collaboration while safeguarding U.S. research interests. The training aligns with federal policies on research security and is part of a series of modules developed in response to NSPM-33.

Training Module Overview

The training module presents international collaboration as key driver of scientific innovation and global competitiveness. It also examines the challenges associated with maintaining research integrity and security. The module is structured around four key components:

1.  The Value of International Collaboration

  • Demonstrates how cross-border partnerships have led to groundbreaking scientific discoveries.
  • Explores historical and contemporary examples of successful international research cooperation.
  • Highlights the benefits of knowledge exchange, workforce development, and economic growth.

2.  Core Research Integrity Values

  • Introduces the foundational principles that govern ethical research practices.
  • Covers openness and transparency, accountability and honesty, impartiality, respect, freedom of inquiry, reciprocity, and merit-based competition.
  • Emphasizes how these values promote trust and responsible international engagement.

3.  Research Security Considerations

  • Explains potential risks, including intellectual property theft, undisclosed conflicts of interest, and foreign talent recruitment programs.
  • Provides guidance on recognizing and mitigating improper foreign influence.
  • Discusses federal disclosure policies and the importance of due diligence in collaborations.

  4.  Navigating International Research Partnerships

  • Uses real-world case studies and interactive decision-making exercises.
  • Guides researchers in assessing partnerships for security risks while fostering beneficial collaboration.
  • Reinforces best practices for transparency, compliance, and institutional reporting.
  • The module features an engaging, multimedia-rich format with interactive elements, knowledge checks, and scenario-based exercises to reinforce key concepts.

Implementation and Impact

The Importance of International Collaboration training module was part of a broader research security training initiative. It has been made available to U.S. institutions and individuals conducting federally funded research and has been implemented in training programs for researchers, administrators, and students.
